newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Good harvests in Philippines but analysts cautious.
newsitem.headline: Good harvests in Philippines but analysts cautious.

text.p: The Philippine agriculture sector grew by a robust 4.22 percent in the first quarter of this year, but analysts on Wednesday remained cautious on full-year prospects due to unpredictable weather conditions.
"Let us not fool ourselves, agriculture is subject to seasonal phenomena. Typhoon today, good weather tomorrow, drought the next day," said Joven Babaan, SBC Warburg analyst.

Agricultural production rose by 4.22 percent in the first three months of the year compared to a 3.04 percent contraction in the same period last year, according to adjusted figures from the National Economic and Development Authority (NEDA).
The agriculture department, however, said the sector posted 2.49 percent growth in first quarter last year.
Alvin Ang, an economist at All Asia Securities, said the 1997 first quarter figures were surprisingly high.
"It's hard to predict if we can maintain the momentum. This summer is extremely hot, I hope rains will not be delayed during the wet season (June-November) for rice planting," he said.
Farmers depend on rains due to lack of irrigation facilities.
Other analysts, however, said they foresaw that the strong start would continue for the rest of the year.
"I think the agriculture sector is out of the intensive care unit," said Noel Reyes, vice president for research at Anscor Hagedorn Securities.
The agriculture department said the hefty growth was largely due to better crop harvests, including rice and coconuts, which comprised 54.94 percent of total production.
"Growth in crop production accelerated and was highest since 1990," the department said in a report.
Production of unmilled rice increased 2.14 percent to 2.58 million tonnes in the first quarter due to good weather, bigger harvest area and installation of new irrigation facilities.
Coconut production recovered from the effects of strong typhoons in 1995, with harvests increasing by 8.66 percent to 2.76 millon tonnes.
"The momentum in livestock and poultry expansion was sustained while a slight gain in fishery output was recorded," the report added.
NEDA reported livestock output grew by 6.07 percent in the first quarter as against 4.44 percent in the same period last year.
Poultry output rebounded by 11.15 percent from negative 1.17 while fishery output edged up 0.79 percent against a negative 0.17 percent.
Analysts said the recent importation of some 650,000 tonnes of rice, the Philippines' staple food, would prevent shortages in July to August.
Philippine rice output is traditionally low in the third quarter.
